The Magic Pharaoh vessel is my 60th Design i posted here .
its well worth printing. on 300% filament printer . or it be a bit small for a non sla printer.
you have to file the lid screw a bit conic and glue the roset on top .
i fill the vessel in the end with some acetone ! screw the lid after its been filed, on . and shake over the sink (don't smoke:-(
open it direct after, than you got a perfect fit.
pore the acetone back in the bottle .
paint with gold nail varnish .

its a huge file i know but it works and its free

cheers Robert

title: Safety razor cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A cover for a safety razor for all you awesome people out there.  
I would guess that they're all about the same size, but I've uploaded the source files in case you need to adjust something. It was created in Autodesk inventor. Almost nothing is constrained. I don't like constraints.   
This fits my razor nicely, which measures, according to my digital calipers, .989" wide, 1.620" long and .350" from the base of the blade to the top of the crown. My apologies for the antiquated measuring system if you're not from the US. Don't hate us, it was Britain's idea.  
The file "razor cover 4" is a slightly improved version of this design that fits a little better. I'd recommend making it first.  
If you want one but don't have a 3D printer, message me and we can work something out.
Print, put on razor without cutting fingers. For best shave, remove before use.

title: Indium Spool hubs for the Solder Spool Holder v2

description.text:
I made one of these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:552536
But doh! It seems to be sized up for a Kester spool. That, and I didn't have any 5/16 rod of any kind lying around. So, I drew up some spool hubs to fit an Indium 1lb solder spool.

I initially had the bearing axle at 7.9mm and the indium spool axe at 19mm. switched it up a bit to 8mm and 19.2mm to tighten it up.

description.text: Recently I made a shadowless lighting rig and highlight lamp. I had some LED boards laying around and I'm sure any boards you have lying around will work as well. I bought 1/2" aluminum rod from McMaster Carr it was 1/2" x 1/2" x 36" square tubing. I also used 1/4 20 bolts (3/4" long) and nuts for the hinges. Use the caps to cover the bolt head and the nut to tighten the hing assembly. The mounting base has a #8 clearance hole with a countersink. Check out the photos of my rig!!

this is a remix

This is a remix of a remix from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:593425 & http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:841709.
These stands are to hold the Nexus Wireless Charger.

The Stands are great but my Nexus Wireless charger would not work through my case (http://www.amazon.com/Nexus-Case-Spigen-Hybrid-Google/dp/B00OH4HOOA/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1439569165&sr=8-2&keywords=Spigen+Nexus+6)

So this stand holds a TechMatte Qi Wireless Charging Pad that works through this case.
(http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00F1SHFJA?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00)

The stand is made to house the Charger and is wide enough to hold the phone in the case. I added some 3M rubber feet to the bottom that hold it really nice(http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001QCXXWS?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00)
STL has been run through Microsoft 3D Model Repair.

Future Improvements:
I plan to redesign the stand so that the USB port on the charger is facing down and I can use a right angle USB cable (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00EBGGXS2?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00), and also breakout the LED on the charger so that it is on the front of the stand.

I printed this stand with IC3D 1.75mm Orange ABS
Nozzle: 239C
Bed: 101C
Layer: 0.20mm
Perimeters: 2 @ 45mm/s External: 30mm/s
Infill: 10% Rectilinear @ 40mm/s

comments.text: Thank you for sharing this!  The other dock I printed which was designed for the circular charger does not work so well since it can not fit a phone with even a basic case on it.   I wish the QI wireless charging was as fast as the turbo charging but to be honest I think a slow charge is better so this is a good option for night time charging.  Hopefully this doesn't heat up my phone as bad as the circular or Nokia DT-900 chargers do.

title: Evolv DNA40 Box Mod - Bottom Feeder

description.text:
Description

This is a variation of this project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:968644

If u need some other different height of push button u can download from this project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:967327

External size are: 92x50x24 mm.

This box mod can mount:

Evolv DNA40 (NOT the DNA25)
japanese square bottle or classic round 6 ml bottle.
If u want print the japanese bottle version u need to merge:

the body with hole u need;
lateral_fit_square_bottle.stl;
rear_fit_square_bottle.
If u want print the rount 6 ml bottle versione u need to merge:

the body with hole u need;
rear_fit_round_bottle.stl.
The box mod can mount a 18650 battery.
To finish the work u need:

a drip cap (there are 3 hole body version);
a spring for negative contact;
a positive contact;
magnets 3x2 and 3x1
wire.
Good Luck !

Use good quality wire, possible silicon wire.
U need 3x1 and 3x2 magnets.

title: Filament Cooling Dual-MK7
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This mount and duct thingy takes a 25x25x10mm fan and can clip to the MK7-dual-extruder-slide. You can clip one in the front and one in the back on the slide. It will provide a very compact filament cooling that wont hinder the build volume. Maybe not the most powerfull cooling, but with one in the front and one in the back it does a decent job, sure depending how powerfull your fan is.
It can further fit four 3mm LEDs to light the work space. You should only put LEDs on the frontside piece.

In the image you see one on the frontside with 4 white LEDs and one in the back without LEDs. The are two additional tiny holes in the rim of the fan to enhance the airflow.

This was designed for a CTC china clone.

The thingy will sit under the slide, in the front and in the back and only add 2mm to both sides, tiny enough to not limit the build volume. Further it will keep enough distance to the the belt and the rods. Downwards it will reach about 12mm below the lower edge of the sliding rods, so it will hover well above the slices.
There isn't much room there, so the design might look a little funny and strange. What you see in the default blue image of the thing is the clamp that clips on the side on the bootom and the half tunnel that lets the sliding rod pass trough in the middle, on the top you see the 4 holes for the LEDs that will face the nozzle.

The thing is build without any support or raft standing on it's back. The back clamps over the front or backside of the extruder slide, the nose and the two tiny notches should hold it in place, in case your slide matches my slide.
The fan must be mounted blowing upwards vs. the plate with the 4 holes. There is a tiny whole in the side to guide the wires trough. I am using a 24V 0.1A fan.
As LEDs best use a short 3mm 120° type. Wire them with a resisitor according to your supply voltage. At 24V I have all 4 in series together with 2x470Ohm, so I only push 12-13mA trough the LEDs, but that's more than enough.
Supply wise you can solder to the extruder cooling fans. So they will always run and you will not have extra control over the filament cooling, but just print your raft or 1st layer a little slower and that will work fine.

It would be wise to isolate the thermal piece and maybe the nozzle of the extruder a little more, as the fans do really blow against these quite a lot. I did not do that by now, so it's missing on the photo. By that the air flow I'm producing is quite warm and it drags quite some heat from the extruders. However I print at 80mm/s and it works, with more isolation it should work even better.

title: FitBit holder with loops for strap

description.text: I have friends with this device and I really like the FitBit Wrist Strap by BSchuler, however I am having a lot of trouble with the printed band (both in nylon and PLA). The little pins either won't pop in or won't stay anchored. So, knowing how rough I and my friends tend to be with this kind of thing (especially when running), I decided to make a variant to work with a velcro strap. Pictured are two versions, nylon and PLA.
I did both versions at .27 layer height, 10% fill, and 3 shells. Temp was 230C for PLA and 250C for the nylon.

title: All In One Geometry Sand Castle Kit!!

description.text:
I'm not really good at architecture nor engineering mathematics, etc. But I know some simple Geometry!
This tool box collects most of the geometric molds you need when building a sand castle, including one big castle mold, one dome, one circular cone, three rectangles, three triangles, three circles, and two hexagons!!
The box is divided into three layers regarding to different kinds of geometric shape! The three layers can finally be stored in the big castle mold!
Now you can print it down, go to the beach, and build your masterpiece with simple Geometry!!

description.text:
I decided to make a case for my Note 4 and put my sign on it. You can print only file 1 for a single color or you can do a dual extrusion print with two colors and combine the two files in Cura or Repetier Host. Also you could print each file seperate and glue or weld the extruded text in the case.
If your slicer does not slice correctly it is because of the thin walls of the case model. Cura and Repetier Host should automatically cheat the wall thickness to 0.4 or whatever your nozzle size is.

title: EASYMOLD =>> UNMOLD EASILY YOUR SAND MATHEMATIC SHAPES with a PARTING MOLD

description.text:
• BEFORE, to build your SAND CASTLE, you have to :

    step 1 - put some sand into a classic mold.
    step 2 - press the sand into the mold to compress it.
    step 3 - try to UNMOLD your sand shape without destroying it.
    step 4- if you don't manage to unmold it , do step 1 again... .

  • HOW EASYMOLD WORKS ?
    The EASYMOLD enable to unmold your SAND SHAPE without damages.
    Indeed EASYMOLD is your MOLD halved in two parts, on the parting line.
    Like the injected molded parts, EASYMOLD separe your geometric shapes mold in two parts, usely in the middle, or on a symetric axe.

  • NOW, with EASYMOLD :

    step 1 - put some sand into an EASYMOLD.
    step 2 - press the sand into the EASYMOLD to compress it.
    step 3 - UNMOLD your sand shape with NO RISK of destroying it.

Finally, You can move your geometric shapes as you want in using the EASYMOLD again.

  • MATHEMATIC SHAPES :

    You can do every geometric shape with this, my adapting the EASYMOLD design.
    cube, brick, cylinder, prism, tetrahedron , cone, pyramid, circular arc ... as you want !
    You only have to put the parting line (separation between the two pieces) on a sharp edge or the symetric axe.

Assemble the bricks or prism or... together so as to build your own CASTLE, BRIGE, TOWER, SIGIL on the beach by doing some tessellation with the EASYMOLD SAND !

You only have to print your EASYMOLD with your 3d printer upstream !

Just try : it will sincerely convince you to bring all your EASYMOLD shapes to the beach =)

Ps : for all thoses you think that SAND is not strong enough to use it as bricks....etc, please try it too or just take a look to the pictures !^^ Sand is usely difficult to handle, because UNMOLDING is hard, but now, it is really easy !

I first made a "monster" in wood to try the EASYMOLD with a hexagon mold.

As it works very well and it was very funny to use it, i try to participate to this #BuildACastle challenge ^^.

Finally, I have design this device with SOLIDWORKS.
Files are now available in .step and in .stl. and in .prt (sw)

Enjoy and post your own EASYMOLD SAND and 3d printed realisation !=)

author: Charlitta

title: Model Rocket with built in camera mount

description.text:
Adapted from the model rocket camera mount found elsewhere on Thingiverse and faired into a body tube suitable for D motors, or with an engine mount for B and C motors.  Note the built in shock cord mount.  This is a work and progress and if someone wants to print it to and fly it (I will be doing the same), I'd be curious to hear from you.  
** Update: My print for this indicates that you should join the lower half with the camera mount with superglue but remove the excess overhang INSIDE the main tube post print.  My apologies, I am still learning TinkerCAD and have already bumped up against its functional limitations.  Next up, Angel Interceptor!  
** Update 2: Added a file to separate out the couplers. I found that depending on printer, they don't 'stick' well if printed directly and would be better this way.  This also allows you to replace them with a baffle so you don't need to use wadding.
Should be obvious how you build this.  You can add your own launch lug and decide how whether you need a C or D motor.  If using a C motor you will need a standard engine mount.

comments.text: How does this fly? Why no fins? Or is there another part I'm not seeing.
comments.author: chall2009

comments.text: I'll know the first week of May when I take it out to fly.  You'd have to add your own fins.  I actually ended up adding a tube and fins just to make it bigger.

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-3uCgtWa0pA

I designed a cooler for the beach that uses the sand itself as insulation. Just place the cooler under the sand and fill it up with your favorite sodas. The cooler also has a tray for easy retrieval and a lid to keep the sand out. To complement the cooler, there is also a set of two drink holders that can keep your drink in its place as you relax on the beach. You can even fill it up with water and freeze it in advance so you can keep your drink cool on a hot day.

Soda Can Holder
•Thin 0.03" walls
•Outer walls have a 10° angle for easy printing and mold removal
•Steepest inner angle is 45° for easy printing
•2 in 1 mold - includes can holder and generic castle mold
•Fits comfortably inside a MakerBot 3d printer
•Fits a standard soda or beer can perfectly
•Option to use the model as an ice cube mold

Universal Cup Holder
•Thin 0.03" walls
•Outer walls have a 10° angle for easy printing and mold removal
•Steepest inner angle is 35° for easy printing
•2 in 1 mold - includes universal cup and generic castle mold
•Fits comfortably inside a MakerBot 3d printer
•Can fit an average sized beverage (water bottle, can, beer bottle, plastic cup, etc.)
•Option to use the model as an ice cube mold

Castle Cooler
•0.045" walls for a stronger and more reliable print
•Fits comfortably inside a MakerBot 3d printer
•Has 3 pieces:
~cooler
~lid
~tray
•tray slides easily in and out of the cooler
•lid fits over cooler & tray
•tray fits four standard size soda cans

The models were designed in 3ds max using hard surface modeling and pro Boolean.

Printing:(print settings I used)
All models were printed in red or white abs with 5% density, 0.4mm layer height and on standard speed without the need for a raft or supports.

This spool doesn't require you to have already printed anything - it just takes a little bit of physical labor.  $10 at the hardware store, a hacksaw or dremel, and 15 minutes and you have a TRULY USEFUL spool.  This is a perfect way to start your first print with a nice spooler.
I've tried a few other simple spools and I've never managed to get anything to work well enough that I felt like I could walk away from my machine during a print.  THIS DOES.

1) Buy this spool. I'm sure you recognize it, it's all over. It usually has a handle and a spool on it, for winding electrical cable. Pop off the handle and throw away the spool. You can truly get it anywhere (picked this one up at my local ACE) but here it is at Amazon: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0000BYDKO/ref=pd_lpo_k2_dp_sr_1?pf_rd_p=486539851&pf_rd_s=lpo-top-stripe-1&pf_rd_t=201&pf_rd_i=B0026GHL9Y&pf_rd_m=ATVPDKIKX0DER&pf_rd_r=1CQKD1DGW6G7DP23NWVB 2) Buy a 5lb roll of PLA from ultimachine.com and pay the extra five bucks for the included spool. It's worth every penny. If you know other suppliers who'll provide plastic like this, let me know. I've got a reel from 2printbeta.de that's similar enough to use with this. 3) Follow the useful visual instructions. Use a hacksaw if you do not have a dremel. In the photos, my first cut is a little shallow; the second one is much better. 4) Put the cut off rings into the opposite side of the spool and push down the top; fit the Utimachine spool in the middle and secure it with some leftover smooth rod, or a wooden dowel, or anything that happens to be handy. 5) (optional) put some clamps on the ends of the rods so it can't slip out -- but it's not likely to slip out anyhow. Secure the plastic rings with a dab of hot glue. PRINTAWAY! This is the FIRST spool I have used that actually despools itself consistently with no intervention.

comments.text: Anyone know where to get a similar spool in the UK? I've had no luck finding one anywhere near as cheap (they all seem to include cable).
comments.author: gcolbourn

comments.text: Update - use this constantly.  Love it.  I wish all my plastic were on the Ultimachine spools.
comments.author: ScribbleJ

description.text:
With all the wild fires and smoke this year I wanted an air filter for the house and I did not want to buy an expensive device that uses even more expensive filters. I designed these clips for my inexpensive 20 inch Lasko box fan. The clips will hold any 20" x 20" x 1" furnace filter. I used a reusable and washable filter I found at Lowes but any 20x20x1 filter will fit.

I designed two sizes of clips. The large clips do hold quite well and would make for a strong permanent installation. The small clips tend to sag and slide a bit, but do work just fine. The small clips are easier to install as they are more flexible.

If I had a garage I would use this while woodworking to keep the air clean.

The small filter clips can be printed with no support, the large clips need support for the small overhang that slots into grill on the fan.

Print the clips and snap onto the fan slotting the front of clip into the fan first and then pulling over the back of the fan. Be sure to put the beveled edges up so the filter will slide in and out easily.

Any 20x20x1 inch furnace filter will fit.

comments.text: So I understand the different size clips but why are there two different clip styles? Like lets say I stick to just the large clips
comments.author: melchiorvester

comments.text: The smaller clip is simply to save plastic.

Designed by Bramante, the original architect of St. Peter’s Basilica in the Vatican, this tiny domed chapel known as the ‘Tempietto’ (Little Temple) was built in 1502 in the cloister of San Pietro in Monterio in Rome to mark what was (mistakenly) believed to be the precise spot where St. Peter was crucified.
The model is 15cm. (6 in.) diameter at the base and 18.5cm. (7.25 in.) high.

The model is printed in several parts which neatly fit together in the correct positions by means of built-in pegs and slots. Fix them permanently into place with a few dabs of super-glue. (I found Lepage’s Ultra Gel works best.)
I printed all the parts at default settings on my Fifth Generation Makerbot Replicator, and no rafts or supports were needed.
You will need to print a total of 16 pillars. I printed them four at a time as in the attached STL file.
Note that the balustrade is printed upside down.

I found the easiest order of assembly to be as follows:
First trim off any errant threads of plastic.
Start the assembly by placing the Upper Part upside down and glue the pegs on the Lower Part into their slots on the Upper Part.
Glue the tops of the Pillars into the little square slots around the outside edge of the Upper Part, carefully keeping them perpendicular.
Smear some glue around the inside of the Base to fix the Lower Part into position, and put little dabs of glue into the square recesses in the Base where the bottoms of the Pillars will sit. Carefully orientate the centre assembly to the correct position in the Base, (The side by the main door is a little longer than the others, so it can fit only one way round,) and snap into position, adjusting the base of each Pillar to fit into its square recess in the Base.
Put a tiny dab of glue onto the peg at the bottom of each baluster on the Balustrade and pop them into the holes around the outside edge of the Upper Part.
Complete by gluing the Dome into position.

Note that there are some lengthy print times involved. My Makerbot Replicator took the following times:
Base: 4h. 25m.
Lower part: 5h. 45m.
Upper part: 7h. 58m.
Pillars (x4): 0h. 46m.
Balustrade: 1h. 03m.
Dome: 2h. 55m.

comments.text:
Hi guys,
I'm printing it at 70% and I really need somebody's help with the Balustrade
how can I improve my settings to prevent this result?
comments.author: Haakon01

comments.text: Stevegong - Just seen your photo of the one you've printed at 50%. It looks great! I would not have believed it would turn out so well at such a small scale.
comments.author: Winslow

comments.text: Stevegong - Many thanks for your VERY kind remarks. However, I really don't think it will print in one piece at this size on a Makerbot Replicator: The distances between the curved wall and the pillars are too great, and the distances between the balusters on the balustrade are also too great to print properly. If you reduce the size, then some parts become too small to print, (as dougwaugh discovered below.) Originally I designed the model to print in three parts. PART ONE: Base, lower part and pillars; PART TWO: Upper part and dome, and PART THREE: Balustrade. This printed just fine, except that the printing times were exceptionally long: The bottom part alone took 19 hours. This is the main reason I split up the model as shown here.
comments.author: Winslow

comments.text: Winslow, this model is gorgeous!  Possibly the best model on thingiverse.  I think this object can be printed in one piece - could you please upload a one piece model of this?  I'll print it today and share pics!
comments.author: stevegong

comments.text:
Dougwaugh - Many thanks for your complimentary remarks. Sorry you had problems with the Balustrade. During trials I printed it three times and it came out perfect each time on my Makerbot. I fully realise there will be problems with it if you are printing at a reduced scale, but judging from your remarks it seems you are printing at the 'original' size.
Darth: You will find print times for all the parts under INSTRUCTIONS (above). Sorry it takes so long. Originally I designed the Base, the Lower Part and all the Pillars to be printed as one piece, - it came out just fine, but took 19 hours to print! - so I separated them.
comments.author: Winslow

comments.text: Winslow -- I've been printing out the parts for Tempietto for the last three days, and am finally almost finished.  The parts all printed out really well, with one exception.  The tiny uprights on the balustrade are very thin and weak at the base, where they attach.  As a result, a few of them simply fell over and separated from the base when I was detaching the part from the build table.  I think I'd better reinforce all of them with a drop or so of superglue to strengthen them at the base.  Perhaps you could change the design a little bit to make their base somewhat thicker.  Otherwise, your model is beautiful, and completely worth the four days it takes to print it out in high resolution.  Thanks.
comments.author: dougwaugh

comments.text: I had this exact problem with the balustrade.  I've printed it on high detail and standard and for both the uprights are both ugly and feeble.  I'm not sure why - I'm at full scale, and EVERY other piece is perfect and stunning.
comments.author: dougwaugh

comments.text: Beautiful, Winslow.  Thanks for this.  I'm printing out the base this afternoon, the other parts to follow.
comments.author: dougwaugh

comments.text: Any idea of the print time?
comments.author: Darth_Revan

comments.text: Darth -- In high resolution, it's taken my printer (FF Dreamer) four full days and most of two nights to print out all the parts.
comments.author: Darth_Revan

comments.text: Awesome work!  I'd definitely like to make one of these sometime.

madamme

Here are four pencil holders, two based on the snub cube and two on the snub dodecahedron. A fifth has been added - a snub cube composed of spheres and hypocycloids - see image. Of the Archimedean solids only the snub cube and the snub dodecahedron occur in mirror image pairs. OpenSCAD has a "mirror" command which makes the alternate forms easy to generate. Four stl files are provided: snub_cube_l.stl and snub.cube_r.stl
snub_dodecahedron_l.stl and snub_dodecahedron_r.stl together with the openSCAD code that generated them.

All the files can be printed directly on the build platform. The snub cube prints particularly well with little overhang. The mirror relating the two forms falls between the left and right hand print in the image above. There is a fountain containing a snub cube at California Institute of Technology in Pasadena - see http://www.publicartinla.com/sculptures/caltech/polyhedron_fount.html It looks to correspond to snub_cube_l.stl?

title: Stepper-driven paste extruder for Delta-type printers

description.text:
This is a stepper-driven paste extruder for delta-type printers, specifically the Rostock Mini. It is the result of a collaborative project at Port City Makerspace in Portsmouth, New Hampshire to build a 3D printer that prints using chocolate. It was heavily inspired by the ceramics/clay extrusion work of Jonathan Keep, though we have since moved away from his pneumatic extruder design.

There are many paste extruder designs out there already. Although some of them reportedly work pretty well, none of them seemed ideal for our use. The goal of extruding chocolate - the kind that hardens, not frosting or ganache - presented some unique technical challenges, especially keeping the material hot while extruding. This would make extrusion over a tube difficult (for temperature control reasons). We also wanted to avoid mounting the stepper motor on the effector, to keep the weight lower, since we were using a delta.

The result is a flex-shaft driven extruder. It is precisely controllable without any special software. Since it is driven by a stepper, you can simply calculate the steps-per-mm of the screw drive, plug the inner diameter of the syringe into your slicer as the filament diameter, and everything will work.

There are still some issues to address:

  • We reduced effector weight and gained precise control over extruded volume with the screw design, but any inaccuracy in terms of runout in the screw drive leads to a lot of friction which can give you stuttering movement of the plunger.
  • There can be a lot of friction with the syringe plunger in general.
  • Managing the springy-ness of the flex shaft is a challenge at times.
  • You are limited in print speed (well, extrusion speed) by the viscosity of the material you are extruding. Chocolate, for example, is very thick and the extruder motor will stall if you try to print quickly and force material through the nozzle too fast.

Please note that some of the pictures above are of a previous revision of the parts; the downloadable files and their renderings are current, however.

Video of a print from this extruder is available here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cwZJkWkvtpE

Additional info on my blog here:
http://gunnenginerding.blogspot.com/2015/06/stepper-driven-paste-extruder-for-delta.html

This extruder assembly requires access to machining tools, or someone who can machine parts for you:

  • The screw drive (ACME thread) has to be drilled and tapped on one end, and turned down to a diameter of 1/8" on the other.
  • The coupler that attaches the flex shaft to the NEMA 17 motor really should be made of metal. It's possible to print one (perhaps out of nylon) and I may upload a printable part for this at some point.

Non-printable parts:
1) Two 6mm (LM6UU) linear bearings
2) One 10mm x 4mm x 3mm (R1030ZZ) bearing
3) A length of 1/4-16 ACME threaded rod and one 1/4-16 ACME nut
4) A Dremel flex-shaft
5) A NEMA17 stepper motor
6) A ~4" long piece of 3/4" aluminum round bar stock, to turn the coupler out of
7) a 60cc luer-lock syringe
8) Various M3 bolts
9) Approximately 12" of 8mm linear shafting, cut into two pieces

Steps:
1) Print the extruder lower and uppers, the plunger holder, the NEMA17 bracket, and the syringe holder.
2) Mount the ACME rod in the lathe. Center-drill and tap for M3 thread. Flip and turn about 1cm down to a diameter of 1/8". (Sorry for mixing metric and standard, but the Dremel flex shaft has a 1/8" collet, so there you go)
3) Mount the aluminum stock in the lathe; turn down to slip inside the drive end of the Dremel flex shaft. Drill a hole in the end to accept the end of the flex shaft, approximately 5/32". Drill and tap a hole perpendicular for a grub screw to hold the drive shaft. Drill the other end to about 5mm, and drill a set screw hole.
4) Snap the LM6UU bearings into the lower extruder half
5) Insert the ACME nut into the slot in the side of the extruder lower section
6) Insert the R1030ZZ bearing in the side slot of the plunger holder
7) Thread the ACME rod through the nut; slip the plunger on the end of the ACME rod, and thread a M3 bolt in to hold the plunger in place
8) Insert linear shafting into the extruder upper section
9) Zip-tie the Dremel flex shaft handle into the extruder upper section
10) Insert the linear shafing into the linear bearings; set-screws are optional, as long as the fit of the shafts is tight. Insert the reduced end of the ACME rod into the Dremel collet and tighten
11) Mount the NEMA17 to the bracket, insert the coupler onto the stepper shaft, and insert the end of the flex shaft into the other end of the coupler. Tighten all grub screws.
12) Mount the stepper bracket to your printer frame, and mount the syringe holder to your effector.
13) Insert a syringe into the extruder, and slide the whole thing into the syringe holder on the effector.
14) Calibrate your printer (steps per mm) and slicer and let 'er rip.

Calibration:
No special software is needed; you need to know the pitch of your drive screw, your controller microstepping value, your nozzle size, and the interior diameter of your syringe (which effectively becomes your filament diameter).

Extruder steps per mm in my case will be:
¼-16 ACME threaded rod is 1/16” per revolution, 1/16” = 1.5875mm
1/16th microstepping = 200 steps per revolution * 16 = 3200 steps per revolution
3200 steps = 1.5875mm
2015.75 steps/mm; put this value in your firmware

Using calipers, measure the inside diameter of your syringe. In my case, it's 28.85mm. In your slicer, put this value in your printer filament diameter setting.

Measure (or look up the specs) for the opening in your nozzle. I'm using a 1.5mm opening luer-loc syringe tip. Put this value in your slicer and/or printer software for the nozzle size.

That's it - start doing your test prints!

title: Locking bracket for a folding camping table.

description.text:
A replacement locking bracket for a common folding camping table.
The original is easily broken when in a rush to pack up after your camping holiday. Now its easy to replace and even in PLA is more durable and less brittle than the original.

Modelled in Rhino, a very close replica of the original. I printed on an Ultimaker in PLA on a 3D-Up in ABS. They print well in this orientation but you will need to print with support material as there is a big overhang on one side of the bracket.
Use the original nuts and bolts if you can if not they are 4mm bolts.
You may need to drill out the holes a bit or just print them a percent or two larger.
You may also want to print them 100% fill (Solid) for more strength but they don't really need it.
You will need to sand the rounded ends smooth to ensure they move freely when folded.

description.text:
Special thanks to theEnoch for providing the amazing photo.

This is a model of Winterfell from the opening sequence of Game of Thrones. I was heavily inspired by damm301's model and used it as a guide whenever I got stuck. Thanks a million! I used screenshots from the show intro to get more detail.

This model was designed completely in Inventor as one part. This was not a good idea because any minor change I made took forever to process. I should have made each structure individually and assembled them together.

I started this project as a challenge to myself using Inventor. Now, I want to take it further and create all the models of Westeros as best I can. Stay tuned for more!

Printed with white PLA
No supports no rafts.
0.15 resolution
2 shells

Unfortunately, the printer jammed near the top... I'll try printing it again if I get a chance.

author: uberkiller

title: Mini Tackle Box for Pen Fishing Rods

description.text:
It is a miniature tackle box designed for a pen fishing rod. The thing houses everything: the Pen pole, the reel, bits of tackle, everything you might need for a mini fishing expedition. The entire box is made from a single sheet of 1/8 inch plywood (18*12 inches) and has a 3D printed cubby for the reel. The rod you see in the pictures above is the Pen Fishing Rod Goliath  and rear drag reel combo (MX 15AA).  
Note: The tackle box will fit any Pen Fishing rod pole  but the reel cubby is designed to fit the Pen Fishing Rod rear drag reel. Anyone who has the front drag reel should be able to fit their reel in the cubby but other reel types will not be compatible.  
This is still a prototype, a better one is in the works! Please leave suggestion for the redesign in the comments!!!

What you'll need: Machines
-Epilogue Laser
-Maker Bot
Materials
-Plywood
-Wood Glue
-Paper clips
-Para cord

  • 5" of 1/4" Wooden Dowel
    -ABS Plastic 

                   Putting it Together
    • The entire box is simply glued together. The way the pieces are laid out in the file are reflective of how its fits together (reference the pictures above if you become confused while assembling) The handle shown is weaved from para cord. You can use many different knots to weave a handle like the one shown above (snake knot). One can learn how to make knots like this (like I did) at www.Instructables.com http://www.instructables.com/id/Paracord-wrist-lanyard-made-with-the-snake-knot/ You'll have to print out the reel cubby using a 3D printer. depending on what machine you use, it could take a few hours. For the bottom tackle board, the one with 9 holes, plug each hole with a .5" long wooden peg cut from the dowel. These pegs are there so pre-lined hooks can be wrapped around and kept readily available for deployment. Between the 3 rows of of pegs will fit two removable slots for whatever you like (I use them for clippers & split shots). The middle layer tackle board is very self exclamatory to assemble from looking at the pictures and the way its cut it cuts out. For the flag that will hold the box open when in use, you'll save the circle cut out from the piece that holds the flag. Glue the circle to the base of the flag so that it can be used as the axis for which the flag to rotate off the piece from which the circle was scrap from (hard to explain, look for the picture and it becomes clear what I mean) In the pictures you see above there is a small box that sits beneath the heal of the reel. the files don't have that part because it isn't needed and wasn't included in the most recent version I've made. The only hard part of the build is the buckles. look at the detailed picture of it above. What you do is take two of the pieces that look like ramps with loops on top and glue them together. You then take two ramp shaped pieces and glue one on each side of the part you just made. That makes the bottom half of the buckle base. Make two of these.
    Next step is to make the top base of the buckle. you take 4 of the square bits and glue them together. made two of these pieces.
    Next step is the flipper part. Take two of the short bars with the two holes and glue them together and on each side of this new piece, glue on one of the bars with three wholes in it.
    Now you'll need to straighten some paperclips and thread them through the hole like you see in the picture. you bend the paperclips at 90 degree angles so on both end right where they stick out of the wood. You cut the rest of the paperclip at the angle and it should stay. I really tried to make this comprehensive enough but i realize its one will need to do a lot of fiddling to get it all put together. There isn't much else to say, comment if you need me to be less lazy and add actual directions on how to make this.

title: Prusa I3 E3Dv6 & Induction Sensor Head

description.text:
This is a Head for a Prusa i3 Hephestos that fits a E3Dv6 with Bowden and a Induction Sensor for auto bed leveling on the smallest space possible.

The induction sensor is spring loaded on a screw which allows adjusting it without having to remout it or fiddle with the nuts they come with it.

The fan duct fits on a "standart" blower fan, and directs the air directly underneath the nozzle, within 1-2 mm, from both sides, left and right of the hotend.

Any feedback for improvements is welcome!

All screws used are M3. Should be straight forward to assemble. Tollerances for the hotend are quite tight and you will have to file a little bit to get a perfect 100% fit. Kept it that way so that there is no play in the hotend.

description.text: A simple 6mm thick Heated Build Platform. This was designed to make my ToM more reliable. As I have been dialing in the Z height more accurately recently I have encountered issues due to slight warping of the HBP's PCB and have had a few occasions where this has resulted in failed prints, removal of Kapton tape from the HBP surface and damage to the HBP itself. As I increasingly leave the printer to do its thing unsupervised and place it in the hands of others I wanted a more reliable surface to ease my mind. Designed in 5 minutes in AutoCAD using the ToM's laser cut acrylic build surface CAD files from here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4973 and featuring countersunk holes on both sides for 6x M3 machine screws and filleted edges all around. I hope to use this as the base of a new ABP I am working on in future too.

• Obtain machine shop access and 6mm thick Al plate
  • Cut to 120*120mm
  • Drill and countersink 6 holes
  • Bevel/fillet all edges
    3a. Enlarge countersinks if necessary for screw heads that are flush with surface
  • Cover in Kapton/PET/Painters tape if desired
  • Install on build platform over HBP PCB (note you will have to file away a small section of the side supports on the left near the bottom for the bulge on the underside of the connectors)
  • Screw down
  • Level
  • Reset Z height & clean surface with acetone
  • Print with added confidence and flatness!
    • UPDATE:
    Please note that you will need 6x countersunk M3 bolts which are not supplied with the ToM kit. I also needed to enlarge the countersinks slightly for the bolts I had chosen to make them flush with the surface. Furthermore I cleaned the Al surface with Alcohol and the Kapton surface with acetone before printing. ABS would not stick to the hot metal surface for me so I had to cover it in Kapton tape.

comments.text: My buddy milled this out for me. It's amazingly sturdy compared to the wafer thin one I bought from Makerbot, which, incidentally, was bent to a full 1mm difference on the outer edges and bowed up in the center.. no amount of bolts can fix the center bowing. It definitely takes longer to reach temp (almost double), but I'll be damned if it doesn't spread that temp more evenly. I've also found that the supplied bolts were not long enough and have ordered 30mm m3 flat head socket cap screws from McMasterCarr ( http://www.mcmaster.com/#92125a140/=eu88pihttp://www.mcmaster.com/#92125... ). Having six holes is overkill, as there is no way you're bending this guy now, although, keeping the heater plate touching in more spots would be beneficial so leaving more bolts connected probably would help. I retract my previous staement. I'll try with 6 for now. ;)
comments.author: MeHoo

comments.text: W00t! I just received my part from the workshop! Needed to enlarge the countersinks a bit with a 5.5mm HSS dill bit and drill press. Even when cleaned with alcohol ABS didn't stick to the metal surface but sticks beautifully to the acetone cleaned kapton coated surface. It is nearly flawlessly flat and smooth, giving a high quality bottom surface of the printed object. I lost about 0.9mm of vertical build height compared to the laser cut wooden part.
comments.author: M_G

comments.text: Sounds like you need an aluminum build surface. It's like the best $9 upgrade you can buy for your TOM.
comments.author: Pointedstick

comments.text: Personally I'd rather something a bit thicker than 1/16 of an inch to help resist the bellying up I've seen on the PCB, plus I'd be crippled by shipping costs and have ready access to a machine shop where I am but thanks for pointing it out eh...Pointedstick. :p

An Attempt at the sunglasses seen at the end of The Man from Uncle

With a 1 gallon can, I have trouble pouring Acetone into smaller bottles for ABS juice without spilling it. So I made this. It allows you to slowly pour directly into small containers without spilling. It doesn't have an air vent so you have to go slow. No more spills. Cannot be made out of ABS if it is to be used with any petroleum distillates (including acetone). You may have to sand the base ring on the spout when assembling because its a tight fit. Created with Sketchup and OpenSCAD.

UPDATE: (9/10/2015) I replaced the spout with a new one that has a flat exit hole in an attempt to reduce any splashing due to gurgling.

I used PLA and it works with acetone. It did discolor but not dissolve. Some PLA contains additives that are susceptible to acetone so your results may vary. Nylon would be best for petroleum distillates. Printed on a MendelMax 1.5.

The first version was an an exact copy of Thumperlater's "Folgertech Delta wire support", that as I was printing it, I realized it was a perfect starting point for a Raspberry Pi mount!

I have re-mixed it with parts from a couple of other Thingiverse projects so that it now has a ball mount, plus a hinge to swivel it out of the way. (It also allows you to position the Pi closer or further away for 'tighter' or 'wider' shots.) I also created a simple bracket for the MCM case that I'm using, but the ball clamps aren't tight enough, so I will be re-mixing them soon. (I currently have a piece of 150 grit sandpaper in-between the grips and the ball to keep the pi from moving [much]...)

PS: The rubber-band is helping to hold the LED ring to the front of the Pi, as the double-stick tape has let go a few times. ;-)

So this is still a Work-In Progress until I re-design the ball clamp.
The hinge also needs a slight re-design to add a spring, as it loosens up too easy, even with a nylock nut on it.
I may also re-design the clamp so that it can be turned 90 degrees to the right to take a "Portrait" video of tall objects. ;-)

I've deleted the original STL, which was an exact copy of Thumperlater's "Folgertech Delta wire support" and uploaded my new design.

Hardware required:

1 - M3 x 20mm bolt For the ball clamp

2 - M3 x 8mm bolts For the Pi mount to the MCM case

1 - M3 x 25mm (or 30mm) bolt For the Hinge

4 - M3 Nylock Nuts



The case I'm currently using:

  http://www.mcmelectronics.com/product/83-16319

Here's a Black version of it:

  http://www.mcmelectronics.com/product/83-16320



Thingiverse projects which I remixed components from:

"Raspberry Pi Camera Mount" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:523304

"Cute Hinge" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:646215



One thing to note:

I mounted the camera up-side down in the MCM case so that I could put the USB connections up top for better WiFi connectivity, plus it puts the Micro-USB power jack on the 'inside' now, instead of the 'outside' and in the way. ;-) See pics for details.



And in case you're wondering...

Yes, my holder is currently in three different colors!!! Here's why: I had originally printed it in RED PLA, but was having numerous failed prints with that filament, and thought it was just my settings - temperature, speed, etc. But it turns out that it's just junk filament. It works great for the first 5-10 minutes of a print, then starts to jam the print head.

So I switched to a small bit of White PLA that I had left over, and the hinge printed out perfectly. I then started to print the ball mount, and ended up hitting my power strip switch and shutting everything off mid-print... And I didn't have enough White PLA to re-do the print. :( - So then I printed it in my new Purple PLA.

I printed this with:
PLA
.3MM Nozzle
.20 MM Layer Height
SUPPORT is needed for the ball head, or it won't print right at all.

Printing tip: If you have issues getting PLA to stick to your print bed like I do, then put a fairly thick amount of elmer's glue stick on the print bed where the ball head will print, or it will probably fail.

The ball clamp from the re-mixed project was originally designed to just hold the lighweight Pi camera in a small case. (The pi was mounted separately). But I'm using it to hold up the pi itself, and it doesn't have enough clamping force to hold it upright. I got around that temporarily by putting a piece of 150grit sandpaper in-between the ball and the clamp. (see pic) That works reasonably well, but I'll be designing a new clamp soon.

Bluebird house 8" x 5.5" x 5". I designed this bluebird house for the Bluebird Restoration Project, which intends to create habitats to bring back the western bluebird. The front door hinges open so that researchers can look into the box to record the presence of a nest, eggs, and hatchlings.

Print the house and door using 10% infill, with rafters (help reduce warping), 0.3mm layers and no supports. Print the house with the opening facing up (back of the house on build plate). Print the door flat on the build plate. Two versions of the door are included: one with steps (as pictured) and one without steps. Bluebird houses have no perch because predators use them to support themselves and eat the eggs and hatchlings. Print 2 hinge pins at 50% infill, 0.3mm layers, with rafters and no support. Pins should fit snug on the house so that the door hinges but the pins don't move out. You can glue the pins if needed. Use a paper clip or thick wire to hold the door closed.

House can be mounted on a tree or fence using holes on the back of the house, or using a chain wrapped around the holes on the side of the house.

Here is the my version of the new pip boy from Fallout 4. Be aware this is as accurate as I can get it with the photos and references I have so far. My design features a operating tape deck and removable game cartridges like in Bethesda E3 conference and fits all the phones the Fallout 4 pip boy editions can hold. For some of the hinges I have intended to use 3mm Dia. steel wire as a printed dowel just won't be strong enough, it will also need a length of 1mm Dia. wire to be used as a spring for the tape deck. Details of which, I will detail when I upload the part files.

The only file attached for the moment is the whole assembly as an STL, I will release the part files after I'm happy that it assembles and operates correctly but the STL still show the detail I have included in the model.

If you want a Fallout fix, check out my other Fallout props;
http://www.thingiverse.com/lilykill/collections/fallout-props

Follow me on twitter @ https://twitter.com/lilykill1, and instagram @ https://instagram.com/lilykill1/ and facebook @ https://www.facebook.com/Lilykill-253119598353137/ where you can stay up-to-date on my current projects and releases.

Update 11/09/15
Just uploaded the parts but just to reiterate, I have not printed this, I will need feedback to make improvements if you have any problems.

Update 23/09/15
STEP 214 file uploaded of complete assembly.

I have uploaded the new files that has the parts cut up to except for the parts for cassette mechanism which I'm still perfecting as I'm not completely happy with at the moment. If anybody prints this out in the meantime, the only part that will need to be reprinted will be the "MAIN BODY MIDDLE TOP.stl.". I will then upload all the parts for cassette mechanism.

Update 17/12/15
Cassette mechanism parts uploaded along with assembly instructions.

Update 18/12/15
BOM added and STL zip updated so BOM is included.

description.text: I use my soldering iron almsot every day. I always have it in my desk ready to be used, but a lot of time the cable is just in the way. This was becoming really anoying for me. So I decided to 3D-print this simple clips that keep the cable out of the way but still give me freedom to move around while soldering.
This was pretty easy to print, I used my normal settings with 25% fill density. I also used a raft, for better platform adhesion.

I have been helping a friend design pieces for a board game he is working on. They are fairly simple and print well at .3mm. Maybe someone else can get some use out of them. The pieces are as follows.

  • Merchant: bag of money
  • Bureaucrat: Gov't Building
  • Archer: Arrow
  • Infantry: Sword
  • Champion: Shield
  • Calvary: Horse head
  • Catapult: duh...

The catapult requires printing four wheels and gluing the axles together and then gluing to the frame. They were meant to be only aesthetic but they actually shoot little pieces of paper and balls of tin foil really well.

Enjoy!
Logomarca que eu desenhei da Rockfordfosgate

Model generated from SVG illustration using paths2openscad (based on Dan Newman's Inkscape to OpenSCAD extension). SVG derived from pen/marker doodle with the Adobe Shape CC app. I did forget to flip the model before printing, so the stamp produces mirror images of the original.

Tested with PLA and India ink. There may be better material combinations. It took a number of stamping attempts before a clean print was possible. I think the surface layers had to get saturated with ink first so that it wouldn't just run off.

Anyway, it pleases me to pull a picture through the full circle of ink to various digital and mechanical representations back to ink again.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Cooling Duct: 30mm and 40mm

description.text:
Designed my own version of the cooling duct to replace the stock one, still using the stock 30mm fan. I uploaded the pictures of the first one I printed...I do not recommend printing supports inside that ring. I literally spend like 2 hours digging out the support material from the ring and some more grinding the edges a bit smoother after all that work. Before uploading I changed the design for it to sit the same height as stock, and made the opening where the air comes out a bit bigger but still not totally open downward hoping to direct it toward part. For support, I think support that are touching the printer bed might be fine, but can't say for sure.

I will make a 40mm version if there is actually anyone that wants one.

Edit: Changed the orientation to match how Thingiverse displays it.

title: m3d and other printer attachement wall

description.text: hey guys, this model can either be printed as one or two, and this model is something that you print and when you print two of them, you put one at each corner of the printer, and slot in cardboard to make it a wall,, if you print 4 of the double then your m3d micro will be fully enclosed,,, and as it is cardboard rather than plastic then there will be less noise as plastic amplifies it,, this will help with warping, almost stop all warping with pla and assist wil abs, and it also covers the motors so less sound if it is in your room, plus i used clear plastic from a box for the front so it stil contained heat and i could see the print.

just print as is, with raft on, if you want then wavebonding, (better safe than sorry) quality and fill does not matter, I iused medium and low quality, and low fill, it takes between 1 and a half hours to 2 hours.

description.text:
Note Updated version as of 22nd Jan 2016:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1285270
I have been busy creating the next generation diverter.

Inspired by a couple of these devices seen on Thingiverse.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:964637
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26844
This one fits a tap aerator with a diameter of 23.5mm.
What makes this different is the annular manifold at the top which helps prevent the aerator choking and keeps it working smoothly to allow a steady aerated stream.
Simply placing your finger over the bottom opening gives nice bubbler style water flow from the top to rinse your mouth or drink.

UPD: I printed another in clear ABS, needed to increase the scale by 2% in the printer software, would have been better 3% in hind sight.
The Silver version was made in PLA, I think items that are going to be in contact with water are better in ABS. PLA can slowly dissolve while PLA is safe I do not know what the colouring agent is, that might leach out and cause a problem, clear ABS should be fine.

I printed this in PLA with standard setting of 3 layers top, bottom and perimeter. I used a 60% fill and it worked fine.
I do have concerns about PLA being in contact with water and I will make this in ABS in the near future.

comments.text:
That one is PLA I am currently using it at home made in PETG.
I doubt PLA would be much problem however while PLA itself is safe the colouring agent in it may not be so use with caution.
I haven't made this in ABS I doubt it would be a problem either but I don't like the smell of it, I would not make it out of polycarbonate though as known issue with BPA.

title: Wade's Extruder Vertical Stand (for Bowden mod)

description.text: This stand allows a Wade's extruder to stand alone when used to drive a Bowden tube. This is an aggressive remix of sponnet's Printrbot Bowden Mod (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26963) which pulled this part from Greg's Wade Reloaded (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18379 ) ** Original file from sponnet used an M8 hole for the bowden tube mounting. I just received my (pneufit) SPC-06-01 Pneumatic Push to Connect Fitting. This fitting uses a British Standard Pipe Taper Thread R1/8". Tap size is 8.4mm for this thread, but I'm 'self' tapping with the thread itself into the plastic. I'm using 9.45mm for the base and 9.15 for the tip (it tapers.) These values are now parameter driven in the extruder_to_bowden_stand_vert_fitting.scad file (and used in the associated .STL file.)

The OpenSCAD file is included and can easily be modded to change thickness or add screw-down holes to the base plate.  I sliced in Slic3r with a .25 infill (would probably increase that to .35 if I print again,) in PLA.

title: Spool Holder v2 for MakerBot Rep, Rep2, Rep2x

description.text: Got some cheap Jet filament from Amazon. It doesn't fit stock or any spool holder I have seen. So I designed this one to work with all the spools I've, Makerbot, SainSmart and Jet. The CAD image is V2, which has R, L indicators are added. R, L correspond to R, L printer heads. Photos are of a previous version, prints with PLA. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/kA29GNnKj5I

I printed this with PLA on MakerBot Rep2x.  It was the largest successful PLA print for me on Rep2x.  Had to baby it the entire time to make sure the filament feeder didn't get stuck.   
Simple to print, with no support.  15% fill, 3 shell @ 0.34mm.  ABS or PLA.  Could potentially go down to 10% fill.

title: Excel G3 Light wheelchair tube closure

description.text:
The Excel G3 Light wheelchair has 2 two tubes that are closed by plastic caps. Problem is the caps fit loose and get lost.
This is a replacement cap with a tight fit.
Printed in PLA, 0.2mm layer hight, 0.4 mm nozzle. Shouldn't be to complicated.
